jobs.title: Team Member
jobs.description: PURPOSE OF POSITIONThe Team Member is responsible and accountable for performing specific tasks and duties, as assigned, within the restaurant. The Team Member provides each guest with a positive guest service experience, prepares quality food products and keeps the restaurant clean.KEY ACCOUNTABILITIESGeneral Accountabilities & Work tasks Follow guest service guidelines and procedures; take appropriate action to ensure guests receive service beyond their expectations Work assigned stations accurately and productively; clean and stock station areas; perform other cleaning duties as assigned You may be required to cook as an when required by your supervisor Handle all food products according to RBL procedures Follow RBL food safety, food handling and sanitation requirements, to ensure the health and safety of guests and employees Report faulty equipment and fixtures to the manager on duty Work Tasks could include: Order taking and serving food and beverage orders. Operating an electronic register, receiving payment and making change. Packing products into food packaging for takeaway or trays for serving, with condiments. Handing packed orders to customers from the packing bench to front counter or out the drive-thru window to the customer‚Äôs vehicle. Washing, cutting, dicing, slicing vegetable and salad ingredients. Measuring and mixing foods e.g. potato mix, gravy mix Using a potato scoop to scoop mash potato into pottles and pouring gravy on top. ‚àô Preparing food such as burgers, wraps and salads Operating cooking equipment such as potato mixer, microwave, warmer timers ‚àô Heating simple food items e.g. burger buns, rolls and tortillasMonitoring food timers for food safety ‚Äòshelf life‚Äô control and discards products Loading chip basket with raw fries placing in to the fryer, lifting and dumping cooked chips from the basket into the chip hopper, ready for serve. Scooping hot chips using a chip scoop into takeaway packaging. Moving chicken trays from the warming cabinet into the chicken display. Cleaning food preparation areas, cooking surfaces, food containers and utensils ‚àô Handling general purpose detergents and sanitiser for cleaning Clearing tables of food packaging, emptying rubbish bins and carrying rubbish bags to the rubbish skip back of house. Training and Development Strive to improve personal skills and performance Relevant cook training may be provided as and when required Communicate to immediate supervisor when additional training, guidance and practice are needed Keep immediate supervisor informed of anything which might affect guests, other employees and overall operations Is performance oriented and driven; understands performance expectations and is aware of performance results Effective Business Management Consistently meet job expectations to positively impact the sales and profits of the restaurant ‚àô Contribute to the restaurant‚Äôs success by accomplishing the expected work during each shift; consistently produces quality work Support the goals, decisions and directives of restaurant management; perform additional duties and responsibilities as directed Follow RBL guidelines for food and cash controls, follow cost control guidelines to maintain and minimize restaurant costs; properly use all products, suppliers, equipment and facilities Health and Safety Take reasonable care for your own health and safety at work, and that your actions/omissions do not cause harm to any other person in the workplace (including, for example, co-workers and customers) Participate in creating and maintaining a safe and healthy work environment, particularly by complying with instructions, policies and procedures Advise manager of any/all work related injuries, accidents, near misses and hazards or potential hazards (including any faults to equipment), and risks or potential risks to health and safetyMOST FREQUENT CONTACTSRestaurant Manager Assistant Restaurant Manager Customers Area Managers Store TeamCritical Qualifications/Skills/ExperienceQualifications: Ideally a minimum of NCEA Level 1 or working towards Level 1 Business/Technical Skills Previous customer service or customer facing experience is favoured but not essential Experience (Behavioural): Places customer first and goes out of their way to ensure customer satisfaction ‚àô Able to work under pressure, remaining calm at all times Works well with others and is supportive and collaborative Focused on achieving results and strives to meet targets Acts with integrity at all times Works within guidelines, policies and rules and is a natural rule follower Focused on the safety and wellbeing of others at all times including customers and peersCommunicates effectively verbally with customers and the team and is clear and concise ‚àô Able to comprehend written English and able to complete online training modules and follow written procedures and policies with ease Manages time well to complete set tasks and works quickly and with purpose to maintain momentumThis Position Description summarises the primary responsibilities of this role at the time of commencement. Various other responsibilities not listed here may also fall within the responsibility parameters of the position. From time to time and with the natural developments of business structure and practice, an employee may be required to perform additional or new responsibilities that fall reasonably within the expectations of this role. Any significant adjustments to role responsibilities will always be made after consultation with the employee.P22-225241-2

jobs.title: Police Officer
jobs.description: Working at Police (who we are) New Zealand Police delivers services that ensure people can be safe and feel safe in their homes, on our roads and in their communities. Police operate 24 hours a day in a complex environment actively targeting and preventing crime and harm. With around 16,000 staff, we work from urban and rural stations and larger policing hubs.We operate on land, sea and in the air, and respond to more than 1.2 million events per year ‚Äì answering more than 992,000 111 calls and over 650,000 non-emergency calls. We‚Äôre working towards specific goals and targets that highlight our intent to work collaboratively with iwi and communities, other government sectors and business partners to deliver ‚ÄòOur Business‚Äô and achieve long-term changeValues: Our Values provide a guide to the way New Zealand Police work, operate, and make decisions, and reflect what is important to us and the communities we serve. Professionalism: Taking pride in representing New Zealand Police and making a difference in the communities we serveRespect: Treating everyone with dignity, upholding their individual rights and honouring their freedomsIntegrity: Being honest and upholding excellent ethical standards Commitment to MƒÅori and The Treaty: Acting in good faith of, and respecting the principles of Te Tiriti O Waitangi ‚Äì partnership, protection, and participationEmpathy: Seeking understanding of, and considering the experience and perspective of those New Zealand Police serve Valuing Diversity: Recognising the value different perspectives and experiences bring to making us better at what we do Position Overview (where you‚Äôll be working) The purpose of the District Operations is to deliver Our Business. To support the delivery of District outcomes the General Duties Constable will maintain and enhance public security and welfare through response to incidents requiring police attention and the conduct of relevant enquiries. The purpose of leadership in this role is to deliver (or enable others to deliver) Our Business. Responsibilities (what you‚Äôll be doing) The Constable ‚Äì General Duties will:1. Be safe and feel safe Understand the hazards in your work area and eliminate or minimise the associated risk.Report all accidents, incidents and near misses in MyPolice in a timely fashionActively participate in Wellness and Safety initiatives and training 2. Service delivery Patrolling Undertakes patrols and responds to situations to enforce law and/or maintain public order by the following: Undertaking patrolling in accordance with organisational requirements, principles of non-discrimination and supervisors instructions in a manner that optimises achievement of the patrols goals. Correctly assessing emergent situations and taking appropriate action Establishing, maintaining and utilising knowledge of the local patrol area Responding to incidents, taskings and requests for assistance in accordance with accepted operational procedures Utilising situational problem-solving techniques to resolve issues Assessing situational behaviour of people and determining/implementing appropriate reaction/response strategies Providing first response control/command and/or co-ordination at incidents Conduct Initial Police Investigation Assesses and preserves crime/incident scenes, and assists in the investigation process when required Collects and analyses information relevant to investigations Identifies, seizes, processes and manages exhibits in accordance with legislative and administrative processes Considers and utilises all organisational avenues of inquiry and investigative procedures in order to identify subjects and persons Conducts searches of persons, property and vehicles with due regard to lawful authority and organisational procedures. Decisions to caution, report or arrest are made at the discretion of the officer and conveyed to the person(s) concerned in accordance with organisational and legal guidelines. Affords rights to suspects and victims of crime by treating them in a fair, equitable and non-discriminatory manner.Gathers, Collates and Records Information Collects and records information relevant to police issues in accordance with jurisdictional laws, policy and procedures Takes comprehensive statements that contain all details relevant to the matter being examined and are in accordance with jurisdictional laws, policy and procedures Completes the full range of complaint correspondence in a concise and timely manner Completes arrest files, not guilty prosecution files, and other correspondence including notifying of complainants, witnesses and dealing with exhibits Conducts and records interviews in accordance with jurisdictional laws, policy and procedures Carries out access, storage and retrieval of information in accordance with jurisdictional laws and organisational Codes of Ethics/Best Practice. Uses interview and evidence recording equipment in accordance with jurisdictional laws, policy and proceduresIdentifies and utilises communication linkages within the organisation to exchange/share informationProcesses and provides for persons in police care or custody Ensures persons in care or custody are provided for, processed and escorted/transported in accordance with jurisdictional laws, policy and procedures Fosters a positive organisational image in the community Acts on opportunities to explain and promote the organisations activities in order to encourage community recognition and support Represents the organisations position on particular issues in a way which acknowledges community concerns and promotes community awareness Advises and involves the community in public safety activities Contributes to the objectives of the Safety Administration Programme S(A)P and the National Road Safety Plan Provides an initial police response to traffic crash events and emergencies Assists in reducing the number of road deaths and enhances the safe and efficient use of roads through: Patrol duties directed at compliance of general traffic law and the promotion of safe driving practices Targeting of alcohol / drug impaired road users Speed control enforcement Promoting and enforcing the use of vehicle restraint devices Providing peak traffic flow supervision Enforcing vehicle maintenance regulations through vehicle checks Issuing Traffic and Infringement Offence Notices Provides assistance/support for: Accident investigation officers Summons service CARD centre Judicial Processing Prepares and manages evidence, witnesses and offenders for the relevant judicial authority in accordance with jurisdictional laws and organisational policies and procedures by: Managing witnesses Monitoring offenders Liaising with and assisting prosecutions section Undertaking post-court procedures 3. Personal professional performance Effectively manages personal professional performance in order to ensure public confidence in the police service by: Modelling high standards of personal performance, ethics and integrity Reviewing and monitoring personal performance Developing and maintaining ongoing personal competence Assisting and supporting other personnel Maintaining personal physical and emotional health. 4. Team work Works effectively as a member of a team within the community Co-operates and works with other members of the section in order to achieve team goals Establishes and supports open honest and constructive relationships with colleagues Takes a constructive approach to team efforts and supports other team members where possible Customer service Ensures all service requests and complaints are met with a professional, customer focused and timely response. Assesses the changing needs of the customer and implements strategies to respond to them. Ensures services are delivered promptly, impartially and safely. Ensures that Policing services are delivered with a quality customer service and MƒÅori Responsiveness focus. Fosters an atmosphere where being responsive to customer needs is a priority. Provides services designed to target general public attitudinal and behavioural change for the purposes of producing safer communities. Provides high quality policing services in conjunction with other members of the team. Ensures that service delivery conduct and performance integrate both Treaty principles and MƒÅori values and principles consistent with the spirit and substance of the Treaty of Waitangi. 6. Relationship management Creates and maintains networks to ensure local examples of best practice are identified and communicated so that duplication of effort is avoided. Establishes and maintains a positive working relationship with other members of police including members of Dog Section, the Criminal Intelligence Branch, Scene of Crime Officers, Police Photographers, Training Service Centre staff and Prosecutions Service Centre staff. Establishes and maintains a positive working relationship with members of the community and other Government and service agencies such as CYPS, WINZ, Victim Support organisations, cultural groups, local government, churches, schools, neighbourhood watch, and community service groups such as Lions, Rotary and Zonta. 7. Universal Responsibilities All employees of New Zealand Police are expected to: Adhere to New Zealand Police standards of integrity and conduct. Comply with legislative and statutory requirements within area of expertise, including employment and privacylegislation. Model the New Zealand Police Values ‚Äì Professionalism, Respect, Integrity, Commitment to MƒÅori and The Treaty, Empathy and Valuing Diversity. Respect diversity and demonstrate inclusiveness. Understand the hazards in their work area and eliminate or minimise the associated risk. Report all accidents, incidents and near misses in MyPolice in a timely fashion. Actively participate in Wellness and Safety initiatives and training. Perform other duties and participate in projects as required. Additional information: (what you need to know) Required Qualifications For selection purposes, candidate suitability will be considered in relation to: potential to perform well in the position, given a reasonable period of time for familiarisation and/or training. personal attributes and temperament relevant to the position. general health which will allow for the performance of all duties and functions of the position (for constabulary employees a current PCT is an indicator of general health). Pre-Employment Checks Core children‚Äôs worker, safety check required. Drug and alcohol testing, as required, according to guidelines.

jobs.title: Police Officer
jobs.description: Working at Police (who we are) New Zealand Police delivers services that ensure people can be safe and feel safe in their homes, on our roads and in their communities. Police operate 24 hours a day in a complex environment actively targeting and preventing crime and harm. With around 16,000 staff, we work from urban and rural stations and larger policing hubs.We operate on land, sea and in the air, and respond to more than 1.2 million events per year ‚Äì answering more than 992,000 111 calls and over 650,000 non-emergency calls. We‚Äôre working towards specific goals and targets that highlight our intent to work collaboratively with iwi and communities, other government sectors and business partners to deliver ‚ÄòOur Business‚Äô and achieve long-term changeValues: Our Values provide a guide to the way New Zealand Police work, operate, and make decisions, and reflect what is important to us and the communities we serve. Professionalism: Taking pride in representing New Zealand Police and making a difference in the communities we serveRespect: Treating everyone with dignity, upholding their individual rights and honouring their freedomsIntegrity: Being honest and upholding excellent ethical standards Commitment to MƒÅori and The Treaty: Acting in good faith of, and respecting the principles of Te Tiriti O Waitangi ‚Äì partnership, protection, and participationEmpathy: Seeking understanding of, and considering the experience and perspective of those New Zealand Police serve Valuing Diversity: Recognising the value different perspectives and experiences bring to making us better at what we do Position Overview (where you‚Äôll be working) The purpose of the District Operations is to deliver Our Business. To support the delivery of District outcomes the General Duties Constable will maintain and enhance public security and welfare through response to incidents requiring police attention and the conduct of relevant enquiries. The purpose of leadership in this role is to deliver (or enable others to deliver) Our Business. Responsibilities (what you‚Äôll be doing) The Constable ‚Äì General Duties will:1. Be safe and feel safe Understand the hazards in your work area and eliminate or minimise the associated risk.Report all accidents, incidents and near misses in MyPolice in a timely fashionActively participate in Wellness and Safety initiatives and training 2. Service delivery Patrolling Undertakes patrols and responds to situations to enforce law and/or maintain public order by the following: Undertaking patrolling in accordance with organisational requirements, principles of non-discrimination and supervisors instructions in a manner that optimises achievement of the patrols goals. Correctly assessing emergent situations and taking appropriate action Establishing, maintaining and utilising knowledge of the local patrol area Responding to incidents, taskings and requests for assistance in accordance with accepted operational procedures Utilising situational problem-solving techniques to resolve issues Assessing situational behaviour of people and determining/implementing appropriate reaction/response strategies Providing first response control/command and/or co-ordination at incidents Conduct Initial Police Investigation Assesses and preserves crime/incident scenes, and assists in the investigation process when required Collects and analyses information relevant to investigations Identifies, seizes, processes and manages exhibits in accordance with legislative and administrative processes Considers and utilises all organisational avenues of inquiry and investigative procedures in order to identify subjects and persons Conducts searches of persons, property and vehicles with due regard to lawful authority and organisational procedures. Decisions to caution, report or arrest are made at the discretion of the officer and conveyed to the person(s) concerned in accordance with organisational and legal guidelines. Affords rights to suspects and victims of crime by treating them in a fair, equitable and non-discriminatory manner.Gathers, Collates and Records Information Collects and records information relevant to police issues in accordance with jurisdictional laws, policy and procedures Takes comprehensive statements that contain all details relevant to the matter being examined and are in accordance with jurisdictional laws, policy and procedures Completes the full range of complaint correspondence in a concise and timely manner Completes arrest files, not guilty prosecution files, and other correspondence including notifying of complainants, witnesses and dealing with exhibits Conducts and records interviews in accordance with jurisdictional laws, policy and procedures Carries out access, storage and retrieval of information in accordance with jurisdictional laws and organisational Codes of Ethics/Best Practice. Uses interview and evidence recording equipment in accordance with jurisdictional laws, policy and proceduresIdentifies and utilises communication linkages within the organisation to exchange/share informationProcesses and provides for persons in police care or custody Ensures persons in care or custody are provided for, processed and escorted/transported in accordance with jurisdictional laws, policy and procedures Fosters a positive organisational image in the community Acts on opportunities to explain and promote the organisations activities in order to encourage community recognition and support Represents the organisations position on particular issues in a way which acknowledges community concerns and promotes community awareness Advises and involves the community in public safety activities Contributes to the objectives of the Safety Administration Programme S(A)P and the National Road Safety Plan Provides an initial police response to traffic crash events and emergencies Assists in reducing the number of road deaths and enhances the safe and efficient use of roads through: Patrol duties directed at compliance of general traffic law and the promotion of safe driving practices Targeting of alcohol / drug impaired road users Speed control enforcement Promoting and enforcing the use of vehicle restraint devices Providing peak traffic flow supervision Enforcing vehicle maintenance regulations through vehicle checks Issuing Traffic and Infringement Offence Notices Provides assistance/support for: Accident investigation officers Summons service CARD centre Judicial Processing Prepares and manages evidence, witnesses and offenders for the relevant judicial authority in accordance with jurisdictional laws and organisational policies and procedures by: Managing witnesses Monitoring offenders Liaising with and assisting prosecutions section Undertaking post-court procedures 3. Personal professional performance Effectively manages personal professional performance in order to ensure public confidence in the police service by: Modelling high standards of personal performance, ethics and integrity Reviewing and monitoring personal performance Developing and maintaining ongoing personal competence Assisting and supporting other personnel Maintaining personal physical and emotional health. 4. Team work Works effectively as a member of a team within the community Co-operates and works with other members of the section in order to achieve team goals Establishes and supports open honest and constructive relationships with colleagues Takes a constructive approach to team efforts and supports other team members where possible Customer service Ensures all service requests and complaints are met with a professional, customer focused and timely response. Assesses the changing needs of the customer and implements strategies to respond to them. Ensures services are delivered promptly, impartially and safely. Ensures that Policing services are delivered with a quality customer service and MƒÅori Responsiveness focus. Fosters an atmosphere where being responsive to customer needs is a priority. Provides services designed to target general public attitudinal and behavioural change for the purposes of producing safer communities. Provides high quality policing services in conjunction with other members of the team. Ensures that service delivery conduct and performance integrate both Treaty principles and MƒÅori values and principles consistent with the spirit and substance of the Treaty of Waitangi. 6. Relationship management Creates and maintains networks to ensure local examples of best practice are identified and communicated so that duplication of effort is avoided. Establishes and maintains a positive working relationship with other members of police including members of Dog Section, the Criminal Intelligence Branch, Scene of Crime Officers, Police Photographers, Training Service Centre staff and Prosecutions Service Centre staff. Establishes and maintains a positive working relationship with members of the community and other Government and service agencies such as CYPS, WINZ, Victim Support organisations, cultural groups, local government, churches, schools, neighbourhood watch, and community service groups such as Lions, Rotary and Zonta. 7. Universal Responsibilities All employees of New Zealand Police are expected to: Adhere to New Zealand Police standards of integrity and conduct. Comply with legislative and statutory requirements within area of expertise, including employment and privacylegislation. Model the New Zealand Police Values ‚Äì Professionalism, Respect, Integrity, Commitment to MƒÅori and The Treaty, Empathy and Valuing Diversity. Respect diversity and demonstrate inclusiveness. Understand the hazards in their work area and eliminate or minimise the associated risk. Report all accidents, incidents and near misses in MyPolice in a timely fashion. Actively participate in Wellness and Safety initiatives and training. Perform other duties and participate in projects as required. Additional information: (what you need to know) Required Qualifications For selection purposes, candidate suitability will be considered in relation to: potential to perform well in the position, given a reasonable period of time for familiarisation and/or training. personal attributes and temperament relevant to the position. general health which will allow for the performance of all duties and functions of the position (for constabulary employees a current PCT is an indicator of general health). Pre-Employment Checks Core children‚Äôs worker, safety check required. Drug and alcohol testing, as required, according to guidelines.

jobs.title: Renewables Service Technician
jobs.description: Renewables Support Technician$100K + full use car + Kiwi SaverA great opportunity to join one of NZ‚Äôs market leading specialist electrical equipment suppliers.We love developing electrical trades people into utility scale inverter based power specialists.Revel in an atmosphere of flexibility, dynamism, drive and most importantly, support.If you like dealing with people and see yourself utilising your technical skills as an electrician or electrical engineer in a support capacity that can benefit customers, then you‚Äôre the right style of person for us. We are a growing company with offices in Christchurch and Hawkes Bay, that is constantly pushing forward into new market sectors within the electrical industry. We‚Äôre not a ‚Äúbrown box‚Äù sales company - we provide solutions to our customers based on sales of our products. A critical part of our offer is ensuring that our customers have the highest levels of pre-sales, commissioning, and after sales, service and support. We offer our technical staff an outstanding remuneration package, full use vehicle, and Kiwi Saver. We offer a supportive flexible working environment with management, engineering and sales staff that can support you on your journey. We have lots of great tools that we‚Äôve developed to assist you and your customers.A little about us‚Ä¶Power Electronics NZ is a wholly locally owned company that specialises in the supply of world leading inverters in the form of utility scale solar inverters, utility scale battery energy storage inverters, variable speed drives (AC motor control), active harmonic filters (AHF), electronic power factor correction (Static VAR Generators ‚Äì SVG, and electric vehicle (EV) charging systems. We‚Äôve been in this market for 21+ years, with many of our staff being with us for more than 10 years. In that time we have sold into a huge variety of industry sectors including electrical contractors, solar developers, power generators, mining, local councils, irrigation, timber processing, marine, food processing, commercial building, electrical network companies just to name a few. We even have product with the NZ military.This is all pretty cool product, with each product range the technology leader within its market sector. Our customers demand robust, precise product backed up by high levels of technical support and service. This is exactly what Power Electronics NZ provides and is renowned for.A little about who we‚Äôre looking for‚Ä¶Support ‚Äì it‚Äôs all about people. Our customers are looking for that person who is prepared to stand up and be counted when they need a hand ‚Äì if you‚Äôre happy with people interaction then that‚Äôs a great start. We believe that the best support people in our field are industrial electricians or electrical engineers with solid practical experience. Our preference would be for someone who has service experience within power electronic devices, is familiar with the power generation industry, and has experience in industrial servicing and maintenance. If you are an industrial electrician with experience in service/breakdowns and maintenance then you too should consider this role. We can teach you about servicing inverters. If this sounds like you, then we might well have the ideal role that will provide you a great future in the power electronics industry.You will have a New Zealand Electrical Registration and current Electrical Practicing LicenceThe renewables support role‚Ä¶We have a role for a motivated Renewables Support Technician, ideally based in Tauranga Bay of Plenty region, but if you've got the correct skills and are based elsewhere then we'd be keen to talk with you. We are looking for someone who is keen to be helping customers maintain and build relationships across the Utility Renewable and Utility Power Quality industries. You will deliver real impact through the support of our high performance and efficient inverter power solutions. This is a field technician role based from home.We are leading the charge of the supply of utility scale Solar, Battery Energy Storage , and Statcom inverters to the Renewables and Electricity Energy Infrastructure within New Zealand and this what you will be supporting. In this sector our customers range from private developers, through to Electrical Network Companies and Gentailers, and are spread right across the country. With a solid existing installation base, and a pipeline of projects to supply and commission in 2025/2026, we now need to expand our support team to deliver the best in customer service. The variety is huge. You can be working on providing phone support for a customer setting up a new inverter, followed by the next call to visit a site which needs a 4MW inverter repaired, or standing in a switchyard site commissioning a plant over Ethernet. Your journey with us will encompass:Learning our product rangeTechnical training with our engineering and service team on Utility Scale Solar, BESS and Statcom inverters.Learning about serial communication systems that interface with our equipment, and the various software tools that we have available to help you and the customersWorking alongside our other highly skilled sales people and support staffWe will grow you and coach you into a position where you will have your own niche of the customer support area of the business to look after. There will be a requirement for out-of-town travel based on out-of-town project commissioning and breakdown support.Why should you apply‚Ä¶?You will be joining the market leader in our field. We have a very large and diverse customer base, so you‚Äôll get to work with some great customers and businesses across New Zealand. Salary in the range of $100kFull use of company vehicleKiwi SaverGreat opportunity for future growth and upskillingYour health and wellbeing is really important to us. We believe in give and take in our working relationship so there is flexibility in the way we work.Family is very important to us too, so we‚Äôre always considerate of family needs in all that we do.If this ad has piqued your interest and you are looking for an exciting, varied support role within the electrical sector, apply now including your CV and a cover letter that outlines how your skills and experience would make a positive impact on our customers. Please send tojcurtis@power-electronics.co.nzYou are also welcome to discuss this role with Jason on 021 449 732

jobs.title: Site Lead
jobs.description: Fixed Term opportunity 18 monthsJoin a global leader in chemical manufacturingRelocation support within NZ may be available About the Company Our client is a leading global chemical manufacturing company, recognized for its innovation, industry leadership, and commitment to sustainability and safety.We are currently sourcing an experienced Site Leader for a Fixed Term contract, to oversee their MHF facility in Tauranga. You will drive performance improvements, foster a culture of innovation and continuous improvement, and manage the site‚Äôs operational and financial performance. Key Responsibilities Lead day to day operations, ensuring compliance with OHS, EPA, MHF, and other regulatory standards within the chemical manufacturing industry.Oversee and optimize manufacturing processes to produce high quality chemical products on time and within budget.Champion continuous improvement initiatives to drive operational efficiency, cost savings, and sustainability.Develop and implement the site‚Äôs strategic plan, including the five year master plan and annual CAPEX program.Ensure a robust safety culture, maintaining compliance with safety management systems, process safety, and mechanical/electrical integrity.Manage financial performance, inventory accuracy, and operating budgets to achieve targets for working capital and profitability.Lead, mentor, and develop a high performing team, promoting a culture of safety, accountability, and performance excellence.Serve as the primary point of contact for all regulatory, compliance, and emergency matters, liaising with authorities and the local community. You are passionate about safety, innovation, and continuous improvement and have the capability to lead diverse teams in a manufacturing / production environment. jobs.title: Geotechnical Engineer or Engineering Geologist
jobs.description: We are a dedicated team of professionals who enjoy our work and like to have fun! At Tonkin + Taylor, we're more than just an environmental and engineering consultancy we're a team of passionate people committed to making a positive impact. We love what we do and have fun doing it. Whether you're designing resilient infrastructure, collaborating on innovative solutions, or tackling complex geotechnical challenges, your work will make a real difference here.As a proudly 100% employee-owned company, we're known for our technical excellence and strong partnerships. Our people are at the heart of our success - energetic, inspired, and committed to delivering award-winning solutions. We invest in their growth, well-being, and career goals because they are key to our success.We have an exciting opportunity for a Geotechnical Engineer / Engineering Geologist to join our growing national team. Based in one of our key offices - Auckland, Hamilton, Tauranga, Hawke's Bay, Nelson, Wellington, or Christchurch you'll be part of a diverse and supportive group of professionals delivering meaningful projects across New Zealand and the Pacific. You'll collaborate closely with local and national staff across a wide variety of disciplines.About You:We're looking for someone who is curious, client-focused, and driven to deliver high-value outcomes. You'll enjoy working collaboratively and have a hands-on approach to both fieldwork and design. You're passionate about geotechnical challenges, including slope stabilisation, retaining walls, foundations, earthworks, and ground improvement.Geotechnical Engineer: A BE Civil (or equivalent qualification) or higher. You will either have CPEng or progressing toward CPEngEngineering Geologist: A degree in Geology (or related field) with strong practical experience in geotechnical environments. You will either have PEngGeol or progressing toward PEngGeolAt least 5 years of engineering consulting experienceA collaborative, practical nature with a focus on delivering quality resultsA desire to contribute to a variety of complex and meaningful projectsOur Benefits:Flexible working options and the ability to purchase additional leaveSupport for professional development, including CPEng or PEngGeol and further studyLong service leave and sabbatical opportunitiesAn active social club with regular team eventsHealth and well-being initiatives (e.g., vaccinations, fruit baskets)Corporate discounts with over 400 retailersModern, collaborative office spaces across New ZealandA values-driven culture - 100% employee-ownedWhy Tonkin + Taylor?At Tonkin + Taylor, our various technical specialists are trusted advisors to Government and non-Government organisations, Councils, and private enterprise. We are proudly 100% employee-owned and operated, and live and breathe the Tonkin + Taylor goal to be "the Best to work for, the Best to work with, and the Best at what we do."If that sounds like a place where you'd thrive, apply now and bring your geotechnical expertise to a team where your work will truly matter.We are proud to be a member of Diversity Works. We particularly encourage speakers of Te Reo MƒÅori or Pasifika languages to apply.
